hints_html: The range of a matrix B is the set of all possible linear combinations of its column vectors.
hints_latex:
The range of a matrix \emph{B} is the set of all possible linear
combinations of its column vectors.
hints_raw: The range of a matrix ''B'' is the set of all possible linear combinations of its column vectors.
question: 3 (c)
sols_html: Since S is the set of all possible linear combinations of its basis vectors, and R(B) is the set of all possible linear combinations of its columns, we can simply populate the columns of B with (non-trivial linear combinations of) the basis vectors of S. For example \(B=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -1\\ 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\) or \(B=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -1 & -\pi & -2 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & \pi & 1 \end{bmatrix}\)
sols_latex:
Since \emph{S} is the set of all possible linear combinations of its
basis vectors, and \emph{R(B)} is the set of all possible linear
combinations of its columns, we can simply populate the columns of
\emph{B} with (non-trivial linear combinations of) the basis vectors of
\emph{S}. For example $B=\begin{bmatrix}
-1 & -1\\
1 & 0\\
0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}$ or $B=\begin{bmatrix}
-1 & -1 & -\pi & -2 \\
1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & \pi & 1
\end{bmatrix}$
sols_raw:
Since ''S'' is the set of all possible linear combinations of its basis vectors, and ''R(B)'' is the set of all possible linear combinations of its columns, we can simply populate the columns of ''B'' with (non-trivial linear combinations of) the basis vectors of ''S''. For example <math>B=\begin{bmatrix}
-1 & -1\\
1 & 0\\
0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}</math> or <math>B=\begin{bmatrix}
-1 & -1 & -\pi & -2 \\
1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & \pi & 1
\end{bmatrix}</math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} S = \left\{[x_1, x_2, x_3]^T:\, x_1 + x_2 + x_3 = 0\right\}\end{aligned}\]

be the subspace of vectors in \(\mathbb R^3\) whose components sum to zero.

(c) Find a matrix B so that R(B) = S.
